data.title: Button for closing a tab blinks on hover, when document is unsaved.
data.body:
1. Open Atom
2. Type any letters
3. Move your mouse under the button for closing a tab

Here is a very short video:
http://youtu.be/NCLCjgLzyBY

data.title: Atom cancels logout on OS X
data.body:
Frequently, even with all files saved, Atom will cancel logout on OS X. It seems to do this to give itself a moment to close. However,
- This behavior is very frustrating
- This behavior is against OS X guidelines and standard practices
- This behavior goes against user expectations

This should be removed entirely, and Atom should never delay logging out.

data.title: Copy and paste using shortcuts duplicates last character from selected line
data.body:
Using the shortcuts for copying and pasting text selections duplicates the last selected 
character to the beginning of the newly inserted line. 

![atom_copypaster_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1464876/2944320/86027e86-d9d1-11e3-90ca-cb7a1aec8f8c.png)
- using copy shortcut and paste from the menu works fine
- using copy from the menu and paste shortcut even prepends the last character of the selected line to the new one.

Plattform:
Ubuntu 14.04 64bit

```
$uname -a
Linux mindcrime 3.13.0-24-generic #47-Ubuntu SMP Fri May 2 23:30:00 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Atom Version 0.95.0-7cdaaf2

data.title: Improve some Win32 ctrl keybindings
data.body:
Similar to #2166, this tries to get Win32 bindings feeling a more native for me.
- [x] `ctrl-home` should go to the beginning of the file
- [x] `ctrl-end` should go to the end of the file
- [x] `ctrl-delete` should delete the _next word_, not the previous word. i've used this for a long time, but i had to find some proof to make sure it wasn't something i just customized for myself. Here's a [reference](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/saraford/archive/2007/09/21/did-you-know-ctrl-delete-deletes-the-preceding-word-and-ctrl-backspace-deletes-the-proceeding-word.aspx) to back up that ctrl-delete should delete the following word and not the previous one.
- [x] `ctrl-pageup` goes to next tab
- [x] `ctrl-pagedown` goes to previous tab

data.title: On Mac Release notes give 'Undefined'
data.body:
Clicking `Help > Release notes` gives edit page with

```
undefined

To update: close Atom and reopen it.
```

`Help > Documentation` works as expected.

My hunch is the resource `'atom://release-notes'` in not built into in 0.94.0

data.title: Ubuntu 12.04 - Warning when installing .deb
data.body:
When I try to install the generated .deb file, Ubuntu shows me this message

> "The package doesn't provide a valid Installed-Size control field. See Debian Policy 5.6.20."

It also says something about installing is not save and the program could damage my system and I shall contact the creator. Installing, anyway, is still possible.

data.title: Added precisions
data.body: Python: won't work with current 3.4.x, should use 2.7.x for the runas module to work.

data.title: Tabulators are not aligned correctly
data.body:
**I've deactivated the soft tab option in the preferences.**
Using tabulators does not align the text correctly. Looks like the offset is not correct.

**I tried this example text:**

```
asdasd  asd
asdas   asd
```

![](http://cl.ly/image/0f0w1A2A1V0o/atom%20tab%20offset%20problem.png)

If someone could give me a hint, where in the code I could look for this Issue - I could try to fix it.

data.title: Uncaught RangeError: Invalid array length
data.body:
I'm getting uncaught RangeErrors whenever I press enter in any document where the tab-width it set to 4 (indenting with spaces). This pops up the console with the following message, and the keypress is ignored, making the editor pretty much unusable.

Some inspection reveals that the `n` parameter to the function is `NaN`. Editing the script-inline and using `(n || 0)` seems to be a workaround.

I'm _not_ using the React editor.

When I use ctrl+alt+{ to fold,  the cursor will disappear. Sometimes cursor presents, but it will disappear after unfold with ctrl+alt+}.

It's Ubuntu 14.04. I built from master from 7cdaaf2.

data.title: Can't run on CentOS 6.5
data.body:
Successfully builds and installs, but complains about a missing library when run.
`/usr/local/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libnotify.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`
libnotify, and libnotify-devel are installed. Looks like it thinks it was built against a different version of libnotify (libnotify4), one that seemingly isn't readily available on CentOS.

data.title: :lipstick: Deprecate backspaceToBeginningOf{Word,Line}
data.body:
Rename functions:
`Editor::backspaceToBeginningOfWord` => `Editor::deleteToBeginningOfWord`
`Editor::backspaceToBeginningOfLine` => `Editor::deleteToBeginningOfLine`
`Selection::backspaceToBeginningOfWord` => `Selection::deleteToBeginningOfWord`
`Selection::backspaceToBeginningOfLine` => `Selection::deleteToBeginningOfLine`

Rename commands:
`editor:backspace-to-beginning-of-word` => `editor:delete-to-beginning-of-word`
`editor:backspace-to-beginning-of-line` => `editor:delete-to-beginning-of-line`

Fix #1791

/cc @probablycorey

data.title: auto indent config?
data.body: Is there a way to tell "editor: auto indent" how to format the code? E.g. I want it to remove unneeded spaces between = and variable names (var name    =   "test"; ) or have it autoselect the whole document if I don't select a line.

data.title: Map key for full screen on windows
data.body:
Just a small note:
- The full screen option in darwin.cson is located under `#sublime-parity`
- However, the full screen option in linux.cson is located under `#atom-specific`

This is making me feel a bit unorganized. There is nothing major though, so I guess its all fine for now...

data.title: Cast opened paths to string
data.body:
Fix #2152: path.resolve() was throwing an exception if given path was not a string.
When iterating through all given paths, each entry is casted by JS to
most suitable type and paths in form of a number (i.e. '1234') were
cast to Number, hence the bug.

data.title: Control-left / Control-right does not move cursor to the next / previous word
data.body:
Usually, on every editor I know, typing ctrl-left / ctrl-right allows you to jump to the next / previous word. 

In atom it doesn't seem to work.
## 

Using atom 0.94.0 in ubuntu 14.04 (installed it following instructinos from this article: http://www.webupd8.org/2014/05/install-atom-text-editor-in-ubuntu-via-ppa.html)

data.title: Sometimes scrollbars will change from Atom-styled to Windows-style
data.body:
Details of Build:

```
  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>git --info-path
     C:\Users\Dev\AppData\Local\GitHub\PortableGit_054f2e797ebafd44a30203088cd3d58663c627ef/share/info

  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>node -v
  v0.10.28

  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>npm -v
  1.4.9
```

Atom Version: 0.94.0-c79ef04 from [my own builds](http://blog.someguy123.com/atom-builds-for-windows/) running on Windows 8 (not 8.1)

I think the issue is caused when opening a big folder. Although I can't confirm this. If I open a source code folder from my desktop (atom on the right), I get the default scrollbars as it's not fully expanded in the tree when first opened as there are only 3 folders (at least not until I expanded them by hand). 

However (atom on the left) larger folders like my entire desktop fill the sidebar vertically, and seems to cause windows-native scrollbars to appear instead of atom-style.

Here's a screenshot to show the difference:
![Example](http://i.imgur.com/RHqVdSb.png)

NOTE: This may be related to the other scrollbar issue where the cursor goes invisible when resizing. Filed as issue #2165

data.title: Add default shortcuts for 'scroll to top' and 'scroll to end'
data.body:
I'm running Atom in Linux.
In other text editors (like Geany or Gedit) you can use CTRL+End to scroll to the last line of the document or CTRL+Home to scroll to the first line. Neither of these key strokes works in Atom.
I don't really know if this is Linux-specific or it is intented to work this way.

These shortcuts are really helpful. It'll make Atom more usable.
Thanks you!

data.title: Resizing sidebar gives invisible cursor
data.body:
It looks like the Chromium build for windows is missing some cursors. I am on Windows 8 (not 8.1) using my own [nightly builds](http://blog.someguy123.com/atom-builds-for-windows/). Specifically I am on version 0.94.0-c79ef04

The issue happens when you place your mouse in the resizing area of the sidebar:
![Screenshot of Resizing area](http://i.imgur.com/dMLZ6r8.png)

This appears to be caused by Chromium missing certain cursors, including the default sidebar resize cursor `col-resize`. You can check this by altering the `.tree-view-resizer .tree-view-resize-handle` style. By changing the cursor to `pointer` or `all-scroll` we can get some form of cursor when resizing.

![Example of all-scroll cursor](http://i.imgur.com/mXAz5MY.png)

I don't know if this affects the other versions such as the Mac and Linux versions, but a possible fix for the Windows version would be to use the `e-resize` pointer instead of `col-resize` as I have gotten success from that:
![e-resize example](http://i.imgur.com/CDqzV9o.png)

If you're looking for what to edit in the dev tools, here's a screenshot:
![Chrome Dev Tools](http://i.imgur.com/T1k55ta.png)

data.title: Fix indenting of HTML tags for instance. Fix #1294
data.body:
## Commit Summary

If you press ENTER before a line, a new line is introduced by appending "\n" before it.
Therefor a previous line of "" is appended before the <TAG>-line.
This line remains unindented, causing a wrong indentation for the next line.
Basically this is fixed by indenting this line (oldBuffer.end.row = newBuffer.start.row).
## Bug Description

As in #1294: If you put the cursor before a tag and press ENTER the indentation get's messed up.
## Current Behavior

![current_behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1194855/2938230/e0334d08-d8fb-11e3-80f3-3896fdc44896.gif)
## Expected (Fixed) Behavior

![fixed_and_expected_behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1194855/2938232/075e9018-d8fc-11e3-925a-34176bcaae63.gif)

data.title: Plain text encoding issue?
data.body:
Create a text file (e.g. Test.txt) in Mac OS X (mine is 10.9.2), and input Chinese characters (e.g. 测试内容) in it, then save it.
Open the Test.txt with Atom (mine is 0.94.0), then you see unrecognized characters: ��������

Vice versa. Create a text file in Atom, input Chinese characters and save it. Then use TextEdit open the file, you also can see unrecognized characters:  娴嬭瘯

I think the problem is about the default plain text encoding. Anyone has similar problem?

### Step to reproduce

2. File->preference->package

Fetching outdated packages and themes failed.
(The error message is messed up again. But once I saw is due to "atom version unknown")

data.title: append git hash to version for dev builds
data.body: Addresses https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1925 and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2140

data.title: Shift + Backspace renders deleted characters
data.body:
OS : Arch Linux

When I hit shift + backspace it renders characters previously deleted in the reverse order they were deleted (it seems to miss the character first deleted). 
Example:
If i type "foobar" then delete it with backspace, then I hit shift + backspace 6 times, there will be the text "aboof_". (_ is a random character)
